title: Why you should start a podcast
text:
Harbinger was quoted in the New York Times story, but was hugely disappointed with the result and dismisses the writer’s argument.

“In baseball terms, I think podcasting is in the second inning, or about 20 per cent through its cycle,” he says from his home in San Jose, California. “So the idea we’ve reached peak podcast is ridiculous. All this new money is moving into the space and we’re not even close to peaking.

Ian Chillag, creator of Everything is Alive: “The fact there are people spending lots and lots of money hasn’t changed the barrier of entry for anybody else."

“When [filmmaker] James Cameron does a podcast that gets 500 million downloads, or the next Marvel movie has a podcast with it, or my parents start listening to podcasts, then we’ll reach that level. But none of those things have happened.”

Such bullishness may surprise Harbinger’s critics. After all, the 39-year-old has gained infamy for a public talk he has been giving since 2016 called For The Love Of God, Please Don’t Start Another Podcast. He says his critics either haven’t heard the talk or they’ve misunderstood it.

“I’m not against people starting a podcast. I’m against people starting a podcast just because they think they’ll make a bunch of money doing it. If you want to make a podcast where you have a beer with your friends and watch rugby and spout off at each other, you should do that. But if you want to do that because you expect to get $100,000 a year and free rugby season tickets, you’re screwed.

“Shows like mine are in the 0.1 per cent in terms of number of downloads. People that are doing those numbers are amazing storytellers, geniuses in their field or celebrities with a massive audience already. I’m none of those things, I just tried and got it wrong for 12 and a half years until I got it right. People are expecting to do that right away, but you have to pull a rabbit out of a hat to make a living podcasting.”

“I made work for a long time knowing it would be heard by no one," says podcaster Avery Trufelman. Ash Berdebes

Ask other podcasters who have managed to grab that rabbit and they all tell you that passion should come before profits every time. Avery Trufelman is a producer and presenter on 99% Invisible, the popular US podcast that examines the unnoticed architecture and design that shape our world. In the last 12 months she has also created two of her own series, Articles Of Interest, about the historical and sociological impact of clothing, and Nice Try!, about how humankind has tried to create utopian communities. She has three pieces of advice she regularly gives podcaster newbies.

“I tell people to make it about something you love, don’t ask for permission and don’t quit your day job,” she told me when I met her at the Audiocraft Podcast Festival in Sydney earlier this year. “I made work for a long time knowing it would be heard by no one and that’s the greatest gift I could give myself. You just need to learn on your own. I had to find my voice and find out what I wanted to do. And you know what? It was fun!”

Advertisement

The truth is that although starting a podcast is relatively easy, keeping it going is difficult. By around the seventh episode, on average, most of them suffer what’s known as podfade, the term coined to describe how there are longer and longer gaps between new episodes and the show eventually folds. In fact, only about 20-25 per cent of those 750,000 podcasts on your feed are actively and regularly producing new episodes.

And with big business now moving into podcasting, some producers fear that everything will follow the money and that the truly individual, maverick podcasts will get lost in the noise and rush. Ian Chillag thinks that would be a shame, but remains hopeful. The creator of Everything Is Alive – a podcast where he interviews improv actors playing inanimate objects (a can of cola, a grain of sand, a pregnancy test) – uses the analogy of the raw, stripped-down nature of punk and the big-budget bombast of prog-rock in the ’70s to explain why he’s not too worried.

“Punk and Genesis co-existed,” he says. “The fact there are people spending lots and lots of money hasn’t changed the barrier of entry for anybody else. I feel like my show gets called weird and experimental a lot, which I’m comfortable with, but there are thousands of people out there doing things that are weirder and more experimental, who should be getting their due. I want there to be risk-taking and I want there to be reward for risk-taking. I just want more new things out there.”

But where is podcasting headed? Jordan Harbinger has some predictions – Spotify will overtake Apple as the most popular player in the market, more big podcast networks will emerge, market share will not balloon, but grow steadily year-on-year for at least another five years.

As for where we are right now in the podcast timeline, Nick van der Kolk can tell you exactly. He’s the creator of Love + Radio, an award-winning podcast from Richmond, Virginia, that has earned a reputation for inventive and brave storytelling about secret lives, twisted tales and morally ambiguous characters. He likes to compare the trajectory of podcasts with the American film industry.

“People talk about this being the golden age of podcasting," says Nick van der Kolk.

“People talk about this being the golden age of podcasting and I think that’s more accurate than they even realise,” he says. “The golden age of Hollywood is basically The Birth Of A Nation until around 1960. That's when American cinema got its language and the ground rules were put in place.

“There are films from that era that are great, but I've always personally gravitated more towards what's called new Hollywood, in the ’70s and into the ’80s with films like Taxi Driver and Bonnie And Clyde. So for me, we’re now in that golden age, but what’s going to come after that is the equivalent of the new Hollywood period.”

So, using that Hollywood model, can he pinpoint where we are?

“Right now?” he asks, thinking for a moment. “I’d say we’re in 1953.”
description: With more than 750,000 podcasts already out there the market might seem crowded, but say insiders, there's still room for more.
